questions.question: Which of the following Clark levels indicates that malignant melanoma has invaded the subcutaneous tissue?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Level V Explanation: Level V indicates that the melanoma has penetrated through the dermis into the subcutaneous tissue, which is the deepest level according to Clark's classification Clark Staging- Clark Level Skin Layer Involved Level I Epidermis Level II (Option A ruled out) Papillary Dermis Level III (Option B ruled out) Junction of Papillary and Reticular Dermis Level IV (Option C ruled out) Reticular Dermis Level V (Option D) Subcutaneous Tissue Breslow Staging- It has replaced Clark staging It is measured in millimeters from the top of the granular layer of the epidermis to the deepest point of tumor invasion Stage Depth of Invasion Description Stage I < 0.75 mm Very thin melanoma, confined to the superficial layers of the skin. Stage II 0.75 - 1.5 mm Thin to intermediate melanoma, with slight invasion into the dermis. Stage III 1.6 - 4.0 mm Intermediate to thick melanoma, with significant invasion into the deeper dermis. Stage IV > 4.0 mm Very thick melanoma, with deep invasion possibly extending into subcutaneous tissue. Reference: SEER Training: Staging Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 711

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding basal cell carcinoma?

options.A: Superficial BCC typically appears with a thin pearly border
options.B: Nodular is the least common type of BCC
options.C: Morpheaform variant is the most common type of BCC
options.D: The prognosis is very poor for all cases

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Superficial BCC typically appears with a thin pearly border. Explanation: BCC has various types such as: Nodular- Most common type (Option B ruled out) Small, slow-growing pearly nodules, with telangiectatic vessels on the surface. The morpheaform variant is uncommon and is the most aggressive form. (Option C ruled out) Pigmented variant of BCC. Infiltrative BCC Superficial BCC typically appears on the trunk as a pink or erythematous plaque with a thin pearly border. Fibroepithelioma of Pinkus Nodulocystic variant of BCC Patients with BCC show excellent prognosis with 100% survival rates for cases that have not spread to other sites. (Option D ruled out) Reference: SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 284, 285

questions.question: All of these are used for flap monitoring except:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) None of the above Explanation: Monitoring of flap failure: Clinical assessment (Option A ruled out) (gold standard)- By checking for flap skin color, turgor, surface temperature, rate of bleeding with pin-prick, and capillary refill time. Handheld Doppler (best method) - It is widely available and can be used as an adjunct to clinical methods. But it is influenced by nearby vessels and can give false results USG Color Doppler (Option B ruled out) - To assess velocity and rate of flow. Pinprick method - Flap pricked to check for perfusion (bleeding) Microdialysis (Option C ruled out) - Insertion of small catheters into subcutaneous tissue to measure metabolites such as glucose, lactate, and pyruvate at intervals. Low glucose and high lactate levels are a warning sign. Color change is one of the first signs of flap failure. CLINICAL FEATURE ARTERIAL INSUFFICIENCY VENOUS INSUFFICIENCY Temperature Cold Warm Color Pale/White Congested, Dusky/blue/purple Capillary refill Delayed Quick Pin-prick Reduced blood flow Increased blood flow Causes of flap failure: In the total failure group, venous thrombosis followed by infection and arterial thrombosis were the most common causes of failure. Poor wound healing and infection may be detrimental to local flaps and can lead to failure, especially when perfusion to flap tissue is tenuous. Reference: Redefining free flap failure

questions.question: Which of the following types do osteomyocutaneous flaps belong to?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Composite flaps Explanation: Composite flaps are defined as multiple tissue components all served by the same single vascular supply, and thereby consisting of dependent parts. Osteomyocutaneous flaps include flaps that combine bone, muscle, and skin. Examples are the radius flap with the brachioradialis muscle and skin, and the rib flap with intercostal muscles and skin, which are types of composite flaps. Conjoined flaps (Option A) are composed of several distinct, mobile segments, each with its own independent blood supply from a major branch. They are joined together through a larger common vascular source . Chimeric flaps (Option B) are several separate flaps, each with its distinct blood supply, which are connected through microanastomosis, creating a linked sequence similar to the links of a chain.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a free flap?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Radial artery forearm flap Explanation: Radial Forearm flap is an example of a free flap . Free flaps are a surgical technique allowing for the transfer of tissues like skin, muscle, bone, and fat to repair significant defects in various body parts. Free flaps involve transferring donor tissue with its blood supply (through a pedicle) to the recipient area. This contrasts with grafts, which lack their blood supply. Free flaps are suitable for: Large, deep wounds Covering exposed bone, tendon, or cartilage Cases where skin grafts have repeatedly failed Radial Forearm Free Flap uses tissue from the forearm, supplied by radial vessels. It commonly reconstructs mandible (jawbone) defects. The procedure involves meticulously dissecting the skin, a segment of the radius bone, and the brachioradialis muscle, all while preserving the radial nerve. Z-Plasty (Option A) is an example of a random flap that involves the transposition of two interdigitating triangular flaps. Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap and Deltopectoral flap (Options B and D) are examples of axial flaps. Reference: SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 319, 321-325

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with a large soft tissue defect on his lower leg following a motorcycle accident. The wound measures 10 cm x 15 cm and involves exposure of the tibia. The plastic surgeon is considering an axial flap for reconstruction. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the usage of an axial flap? the flap's longitudinal axis. results defects

options.A: Axial pattern flaps derive their blood supply directly from a fasciocutaneous artery that runs beneath
options.B: It allows for a larger flap design compared to random pattern flaps and delivers better cosmetic
options.C: Deltopectoral flap is a type of axial flap
options.D: Due to larger size, axial flaps require a high complexity, multi-step method for reconstruction of

questions.explanation: reconstruction of defects Correct Answer: D) Due to larger size, axial flaps require a high complexity, multi-step method for reconstruction of defects. Explanation: Axial flaps can provide a low complexity, one-step method for reconstruction for defects that are larger in area. An axial pattern flap incorporates an anatomically named vascular pedicle. Axial pattern flaps derive their blood supply directly from this fasciocutaneous artery that runs beneath the flap's longitudinal axis. (Option A ruled out) These arteries ensure blood supply to the subdermal plexus and guarantee blood supply to the flap. It allows for a larger flap design compared to random pattern flaps and delivers better cosmetic results (Option B ruled out) Examples of axial flaps include: Deltopectoral flap (Option C ruled out) Nasolabial flap off of the angular vessels Paramedian forehead flap off of the supratrochlear vessels Facial artery musculo-mucosal flap Melolabial flap Reference: SRB’s Manual of General Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 320, 321 Axial Flaps Pubmed

questions.question: Regarding the use of random flaps in grafting, which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.A: V-Y Plasty is a random flap used for fingertips and extremities
options.B: Random flaps rely on perfusion from the subdermal vascular plexus which is a low-pressure system
options.C: Z-Plasty is used for lengthening of tissue and scars.
options.D: Due to the tenuous blood supply, a minimum length-width ratio of 3:1 is required

questions.explanation: required Correct Answer: D) Due to the tenuous blood supply, a minimum length-width ratio of 3:1 is required. Explanation: Random flaps have a tenuous blood supply. Due to this reason, designing these flaps with a length-width ratio not exceeding 3:1 is advisable. Random pattern blood supply flaps rely on perfusion from the subdermal vascular plexus, a low-pressure system vulnerable to compromise under excessive twisting or stretching. (Option B ruled out) There are 2 types of random flaps used for grafting purposes: V-Y Plasty Z-Plasty Used for fingertips and extremities. (Option A ruled out) Used for lengthening of tissue and scars (Option C ruled out)

questions.question: A 48-year-old man presents with a progressively enlarging, painless mass in his groin. A biopsy confirms a diagnosis of soft tissue sarcoma. Which of the following characteristics would most likely increase the probability of lymph node involvement in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : C) Rhabdomyosarcoma histotype Explanation : Rhabdomyosarcoma histotype: Rhabdomyosarcoma is one of the few soft tissue sarcomas with a predilection for lymphatic spread, making this histotype particularly important when considering lymph node involvement. Spread of Sarcomas: Soft tissue sarcomas typically spread hematogenously to distant organs such as the lungs. However, lymphatic spread, although uncommon, is seen more frequently in certain sarcoma subtypes and under specific conditions. Sarcomas which are known to potentially spread through the lymphatic system: Rhabdomyosarcoma Synovial Sarcoma Undifferentiated Pleomorphic Liposarcoma (MFH) Angiosarcoma Epithelioid Sarcoma Clear Cell Sarcoma Liposarcoma Tumor Size >5 cm (Option A): While large size increases the overall risk of metastasis, it does not specifically predispose to lymph node involvement. High-grade histology (Option B): Similar to tumor size, high-grade tumors are more likely to metastasize, but this typically occurs via the bloodstream. Deep location relative to fascia (Option D): This factor primarily influences the potential for local invasion and hematogenous spread rather than lymphatic dissemination. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 740

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman with a family history of multiple cancers presents with a soft tissue mass. Genetic testing reveals a TP53 mutation. Which of the following is the most likely clinical course associated with her condition?

options.B: Increased risk of developing gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST)
options.C: High likelihood of developing soft tissue sarcomas, breast cancer, and brain tumors
options.D: Predominantly risk of osteosarcoma and leukemia

questions.explanation: tumors Correct Answer: C) High likelihood of developing soft tissue sarcomas, breast cancer, and brain tumors Explanation: Li-Fraumeni syndrome is characterized by a mutation in the TP53 gene , significantly increasing the risk of various malignancies, particularly soft tissue sarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, and adrenocortical carcinoma. This syndrome leads to a broad spectrum of cancer risks, often manifesting at a young age. Soft tissue sarcomas are a diverse group of malignancies originating from mesenchymal tissues. Associated Syndromes with Soft Tissue Sarcomas: Syndrome Mutated Gene(s) Clinical Features Li-Fraumeni Syndrome TP53 High risk of soft tissue sarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, osteosarcoma, adrenocortical carcinoma, and other early-onset cancers. Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) NF1 Development of multiple neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors. Gardner's Syndrome APC Associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), desmoid tumors (a type of aggressive fibromatosis), and colorectal cancer. Hereditary Retinoblastoma RB1 Increased risk of retinoblastoma, osteosarcoma, and other soft tissue sarcomas; typically present in childhood. Werner Syndrome WRN Premature aging, increased risk of various cancers including soft tissue sarcomas, especially in older adults. Gorlin Syndrome (NBCCS) PTCH1 Increased risk of basal cell carcinomas, jaw cysts, medulloblastomas, and rare occurrences of soft tissue sarcomas like rhabdomyosarcoma. Clinical Features of Soft Tissue Sarcomas: Lump or Mass : palpable mass, often in the extremities or trunk. Painless. Painful if the tumor is pressing on nerves or muscles. Rapid Growth in Size : Many sarcomas grow quickly over weeks to months. Tumors are often large at the time of diagnosis, with many exceeding 5 cm in diameter. Metastasis: Most common through hematogenous spread. Development of multiple benign lipomas (Option A): This is more characteristic of conditions like familial multiple lipomatosis , not Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Increased risk of developing gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) (Option B): GISTs are associated with other syndromes, such as neurofibromatosis type 1 or Carney's triad, not typically with Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Predominantly risk of osteosarcoma and leukemia (Option D): While these cancers can occur in Li-Fraumeni syndrome, the broader risk includes soft tissue sarcomas, breast cancer, and brain tumors. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 734, 735

questions.question: All of the following conditions resolve spontaneously in an infant except
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Port wine stain Explanation: Port wine stain appears at birth. It represents progressive ectasia of the superficial vascular plexus mostly involving the face. It grows along with the child and persists throughout life. A 585 nm pulsed dye laser is usually used to treat it. Strawberry angioma (Option B) is a type of capillary hemangioma. it appears 1-3 weeks after birth and spontaneously regresses by 9 years of age. Salmon patch (Option C) also known as stroke bite is present since birth, which develops due to vascular ectasia and disappears by the age of 1 year. Cock’s peculiar tumor(Option D) is an infected cyst of the scalp and usually resolves on it’s own without the need for any intervention.

questions.question: A 28-year-old female patient came to OPD complaining of swelling on the side of her face. On examination, the swelling was painless, smooth, soft, and non-tender. A CT scan was done to rule out dural attachment and a diagnosis of angular dermoid was made. How will you manage the case?

options.C: Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Surgical excision Explanation : Angular dermoid is a type of dermoid cyst that commonly occurs as a smooth, non-tender, soft swelling at the fronto-zygomatic suture. The formation of an angular dermoid is due to the sequestration of ectodermal tissue during embryonic development, which gives rise to a cyst containing dermal elements like hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and sweat glands. Angular dermoids are most often located near the lateral canthus , which is the outer corner of the eye where the upper and lower eyelids meet. They may also occur near suture lines of the skull. They are usually asymptomatic unless they become large enough to cause pressure effects on adjacent structures or become infected. Diagnosis and Treatment: Imaging: Ultrasound or CT scans may be used to evaluate the extent of the cyst, especially if deep or orbital involvement is suspected. Surgical Excision: Complete surgical excision is the treatment of choice , especially if the cyst is causing cosmetic concerns or other symptoms. Careful dissection is required to ensure that the cyst is fully

questions.question: A 64-year-old male patient came to the OPD with complaints of swelling on the back of the neck. O/E the swelling is soft and doughy to the touch and non-tender. A diagnosis of lipoma is made. What is the definitive management of this condition?

options.B: Wide local excision with sentinel node biopsy
options.C: Excision of the cyst with the wall
options.D: Incision and drainage followed by excision

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Surgical excision Explanation: A lipoma is a benign tumor composed of mature adipocytes (fat cells) and is the most common soft tissue tumor. These tumors are generally soft, mobile, and painless masses found beneath the skin. Most frequently found on the trunk, shoulders, neck, and arms. Histologically, lipomas consist of mature fat cells that are identical to normal adipose tissue but are encapsulated

questions.question: A patient came with complaints of a painful swelling present on the trunk. On examination, tenderness and pus discharge present with a black-colored punctum seen. A provisional diagnosis of an infected sebaceous cyst is made. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

options.B: It is a type of retention cyst
options.C: Black colored punctum is present on the cyst
options.D: There is the proliferation of epidermal cells

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) It contains sebum Explanation: Sebaceous cyst is a type of retention cyst. (Option B ruled out) It's a misnomer, it does not originate from sebaceous glands, it occurs due to the proliferation of epidermal cells. (Option D ruled out) Black colored punctum is present on the center of the cyst. (Option C ruled out) Content: white creamy material (desquamated epithelial cells and keratin) Management: Infected cyst - Incision and drainage followed by excision of the cyst with the wall. questions.question: The following are good prognostic factors for melanoma except

options.A: No or very few mitoses (<1 per mm sq)

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Absence of Regression. Explanation : Regression is defined as the partial or complete disappearance of a previously present tumor in the absence of therapeutic interventions or physical trauma. Microscopically it is characterized by the replacement of melanoma cells by dense inflammatory cell infiltrate or dermal fibrosis. Favorable prognostic factors of Malignant melanoma are: Thinner tumor growth (Option D ruled out) No or very few mitoses (Option A ruled out) Regression Lack of ulceration (Option B ruled out) Absence of metastasis in the sentinel lymph node A brisk tumor-infiltrating lymphocyte response Variants of Malignant melanoma: 1. Amelanotic melanoma: They arise from cells that do not make melanin Tumor appears as pink/red/purple/normal skin This leads to delay in diagnosis, poor prognosis, and high recurrence rate Clinical features: asymmetrical shape and irregular faintly pigmented borders 2. Desmoplastic melanoma: Most commonly seen in head and neck There is a high chance of perineural invasion Managed by wide local excision with sufficient margin to prevent local recurrence

questions.question: A patient with a skin graft is experiencing mild swelling and oozing at the graft site 24 hours after surgery. Which phase of graft take is most likely occurring?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Imbibition Explanation: During the imbibition phase , which occurs within the first 24-48 hours, the graft survives through the diffusion of nutrients and plasma from the recipient bed. The process of skin graft healing is called “Skin graft Take.” The phases of graft take involve a series of 3 steps critical for the successful integration of a graft into the recipient site. These phases are: Serum Imbibition (Plasmatic Circulation): In the first 48 hours, the graft is sustained by plasma exudate from the capillaries in the host bed. Revascularization (Option C ruled out) : After 48 hours, two key processes commence. Neovascularization , where new blood vessels grow from the recipient site into the graft, and inosculation , where graft and host vessels form direct connections. Organization: This phase begins immediately after grafting, with a fibrin layer forming at the graft-bed interface to stabilize the graft. By day 7, this layer is replaced by fibroblasts, and by days 10 to 14, the graft is typically well-adhered to the underlying bed. Inflammation (Option B) is a general response to injury but is not a phase of graft take. Imbibition, not inflammation, occurs within the first 24 hours. Maturation (Option D) happens weeks to months after grafting. It is too late to be the phase occurring within 24 hours. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1917

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about malignant melanoma?

options.A: CK-20 is a positive marker for malignant melanoma
options.B: Lentigo Maligna is the most malignant type of malignant melanoma
options.C: Lymphatic spread is the common route of metastasis
options.D: Most common site of metastasis is the Lymph Node

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Lymphatic spread is the common route of metastasis Explanation: Characteristic features of malignant melanoma Most common route of spread: Lymphatic Most common site of metastasis: Liver (Option D ruled out) Malignant melanoma arises from the malignant transformation of junctional melanocytes, situated at the dermo-epidermal junction. Positive markers for malignant melanoma: S-100 HMB 45 Vimentin Negative marker for malignant melanoma: CK-20 (Option A ruled out) Risk Factors: Xeroderma pigmentosum Exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation Family history of malignant melanoma Presence of dysplastic nevus Large congenital melanocytic nevus Multiple melanocytic nevi History of sunburn Types of Malignant Melanoma: Superficial Spreading: Most prevalent type Most commonly found on the torso Nodular: Second most common type Most aggressive form Exhibits only vertical growth Typically occurs on the head and neck Lentigo Maligna: Least malignant form (Option B ruled out) Common in elderly individuals Primarily found on the face (sun-exposed areas) Acral Lentiginous: Least frequent type Has the worst prognosis Most often located on the sole of the foot (under the great toenail) Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 705-711

questions.question: A 70-year-old male presents with a large, aggressive squamous cell carcinoma on his lower lip. After initial treatment attempts, the tumor remains persistent. Which of the following treatment options is most appropriate to ensure complete removal of the tumor while minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissue?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Mohs Micrographic Surgery Explanation: Mohs Micrographic Surgery is a specialized surgical technique used for treating large, aggressive, or recurrent SCCs. It involves the serial excision of the tumor in small increments with immediate microscopic analysis of each layer to ensure complete removal of cancerous tissue. Pathology: Most Common Variety of SCC : Ulcerative type Histopathology Findings : Presence of cell nests, epithelial pearls, and keratin pearls Clinical Features: Appearance: Nodules or ulcers Characteristics : Everted edges with indurated (hardened) bases Investigation: Preferred Diagnostic Method: Wedge biopsy Treatment: For Small or Non-invasive SCCs: Wide local excision , typically with a 2 cm margin (Option C) For Large, Aggressive, or Recurrent Tumors, or those in Vital/Cosmetic Areas: Mohs Micrographic Surgery Cryotherapy (Option A): involves freezing the tumor with liquid nitrogen. Used for superficial skin cancers or precancerous lesions. Electrodesiccation and curettage (Option B) involve scraping away the cancerous tissue and using an electrical current. This method is generally used for superficial skin cancers. Reference: SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 281-283

questions.question: A 65-year-old farmer presents with a persistent, scaly lesion on his ear. The lesion has irregular, everted edges and has been gradually growing as shown below. Which of the following is the most common causative factor for his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sunlight Exposure Explanation: Sunlight exposure is the most common and significant cause of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin. UV radiation from the sun causes direct DNA damage to skin cells, leading to mutations and increased risk of developing SCC. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) Also known as epidermoid carcinoma. It is the second most common type of skin cancer. It is particularly prevalent among individuals with fairer skin. It is the most common cancer in darker-skinned individuals. The cancer originates from the prickle cell layer of the epidermis. A defining characteristic of SCC is its tendency to migrate outward toward the skin's surface, often with everted edges. The primary cause of SCC is prolonged exposure to sunlight. The most commonly involved areas are (parts exposed to sunlight) Ears, Cheeks, Lower lip, and back of hands. Predisposing Factors: Actinic keratosis (senile keratosis) Prolonged sunlight exposure Radiation exposure (Option D ruled out) Infection with Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Immunosuppression or HIV Exposure to arsenic (Option B ruled out) Bowen’s disease Tobacco use (Option A ruled out) Xeroderma pigmentosa Reference: SRB's Manual of Surgery , 6th Edition, Page 281-282

questions.question: A 62-year-old male presents with a slow-growing, pearly nodule on his nose. The lesion shows telangiectatic vessels on its surface and has a central depression. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic method to confirm the diagnosis of this skin lesion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Wedge Biopsy Explanation: A wedge biopsy is the preferred method for diagnosing basal cell carcinoma because it allows examination of the edges where the cancer is likely to be most active, providing a more comprehensive assessment of the lesion's extent and ensuring that the entire affected area is evaluated. Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC): Also known as Rodent Ulcer . Locally invasive , meaning it destroys surrounding tissues. Referred to as Tear Cancer, as it occurs typically above a line drawn from the ear lobule to the corner of the mouth. Originates from the basal layer of the epidermis . The most common site is the nose, with the inner canthus being another frequent location. Types of BCC (based on pathology): Nodular: The most common type. Appears as small, slow-growing pearly nodules. Characterized by telangiectatic vessels on the surface. Notable for a central depression called umbilication It can also be pigmented. Cystic Superficial Management: For non-aggressive tumors on the trunk or extremities, wide local excision with a 2 cm margin is usually sufficient. For large, aggressive tumors affecting vital or cosmetic areas, or recurrent tumors, Mohs micrographic surgery is recommended. Punch Biopsy (Option A) does not provide information regarding the margins of the lesion or its depth. Excisional Biopsy (Option C) involves removing the entire lesion and surrounding tissue but a wedge biopsy is preferred over an excisional biopsy.

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presents with a non-healing ulcer on the popliteal surface of his leg that has been present for several months. The ulcer developed at the site of a burn scar he sustained 30 years ago. On examination, the ulcer is painless, slow-growing, and has irregular borders as shown in the image? What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

options.B: Wide local excision followed by flap cover
options.C: Wide local excision followed by flap cover and radiotherapy

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Wide local excision followed by flap cover Explanation: The clinical scenario and image suggest that the patient has Marjolin’s ulcer. Management of Marjolin’s ulcer consists of wide local excision followed by flap cover . Radiotherapy should be avoided as it is radio-resistant and also to prevent obliterative endarteritis. On examination, you observe a well-defined lesion with the following characteristics: The deepest part of the lesion shows exposed muscle tissue. The exposed surface appears red and moist with some granulation tissue. There is a distinct boundary between healthy skin and the wound. A narrow area surrounds the wound where the skin appears different from both the healthy skin and the wound itself. Based on this clinical scenario, which of the following correctly matches the described features with the parts of an ulcer? Edge; Narrow surrounding area - Margin Margin; Narrow surrounding area - Edge Margin; Narrow surrounding area - Edge Floor; Narrow surrounding area - Margin

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of fasciocutaneous flap?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Tensor fascia lata flap Explanation: The tensor fascia lata flap is a type of muscle flap. Types of flap based on the type of tissue and source of blood supply are listed in the table below: Anatomical types based on type of tissue Cutaneous flap Forehead flap, Deltopectoral flap Fasciocutaneous flap Radial forearm flap, Scapular flap, Lateral arm flap, Groin flap (Option A, B & D ruled out) Muscle flap Gluteus maximus muscle flap, Gracilis flap, Tensor fascia lata muscle flap Myocutaneous flap Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap, Latissimus dorsi flap—composite flap Osteomyocutaneous flaps Radius with brachioradialis and skin—composite flap, Rib with intercostal muscles and skin—composite flap Anatomical types based on the source of vascular supply Random Pattern Flap Rely on low pressure found in subdermal plexus Used to reconstruct small but full-thickness defect Not amenable to skin grafting Axial Flap Based on the named vessel If the axial flap remains attached to its proximal blood supply & transferred to a defect known as pedicle flap Free Flap Autogenous transplant of vascularized tissues There is devascularization from donor site & revascularization at recipient bed

questions.question: Which of the following is not an absolute indication for flap surgery?

options.B: Exposed bony prominences in the joint area

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Stage III bedsores Explanation: Stage III bedsores are primarily managed by Debridement and dressing with Vacuum-assisted closure, also known as negative pressure dressing. There is no requirement for flap surgery. However, Stage IV bedsores require flap reconstruction with the help of Tensor fascia lata flap . Absolute indications of flap reconstruction are mentioned below: Exposed bone Exposed brain Post-burn contractures (Option A) Radiated vessel (Option C) Pressure sore at bony prominence (Stage IV) Open joints or non-biological implant materials (Option B) Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 319-322 Elsevier Burns

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient with extensive third-degree burns requires skin grafting. The surgical team opts for a meshed split-thickness skin graft (STSG). Which of the following is a key benefit of using a meshed skin graft in this scenario?

options.B: Coverage of a large area with minimal donor skin

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Coverage of a large area with minimal donor skin Explanation: A meshed split-thickness skin graft (STSG) is particularly advantageous in cases of extensive burns because it allows for the expansion of the graft over a larger surface area with limited donor skin. By creating tiny splits in the graft, the skin can be stretched, enabling it to cover more extensive areas, which is critical in managing large burn wounds. These splits also facilitate fluid egress, which helps the graft conform to the wound bed, ensuring better contour matching. The ideal meshing ratio typically ranges from 1:1.5 to 1:6 , depending on the area that needs coverage. Despite its utility, the meshed skin graft has some drawbacks, including a less favorable cosmetic appearance due to the visible mesh pattern and a higher degree of secondary contraction , which can lead to scarring . Enhanced cosmetic appearance (Option A) : While meshed skin grafts are effective for large-area coverage, they often result in poor cosmetic outcomes due to the visible mesh pattern and increased secondary contraction. Reduced risk of secondary contraction (Option C) : Meshed grafts actually have a higher risk of secondary contraction, which can affect the cosmetic outcome. Decreased need for vascularization (Option D) : Vascularization is essential for the graft to take properly and ensure its integration with the wound bed.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male undergoes a split-thickness skin graft for a large wound on his leg. Three days postoperatively, the graft appears swollen with fluid accumulating underneath it. Which of the following complications is most likely?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hematoma or seroma formation Explanation: In this scenario, the accumulation of fluid beneath the graft is indicative of hematoma or seroma formation. This complication can prevent proper adherence of the graft to the wound bed, leading to graft failure if not addressed promptly. Hematomas are collections of blood, while seromas are accumulations of clear fluid. Both can occur when there is inadequate hemostasis or when there is excessive movement or pressure on the graft site post-operatively. Complications of Skin Grafting: Graft Failure (Option A) : This occurs when the graft does not survive or integrate with the recipient site, due to poor vascularization or improper placement. It is not characterized by fluid accumulation beneath the graft. It can be prevented by ensuring good contact between the graft and the wound bed and avoiding movement or pressure on the graft. Infection (Option C) : Infection typically presents with redness, warmth, and pus rather than just fluid accumulation. Strict sterile techniques during surgery and the use of prophylactic antibiotics can help prevent infections. Hematoma or Seroma Formation (Option B) : These complications occur when blood or fluid collects under the graft. Proper hemostasis during surgery and the use of drains can prevent this issue. Poor Cosmetic Outcome (Option D) : If the graft does not match the recipient site's skin texture or thickness, or if it is not placed correctly, the cosmetic result may be unsatisfactory. Careful selection of graft thickness and meticulous placement can help achieve a better aesthetic outcome. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1917

questions.question: A patient needs a graft to cover a small, non-weight-bearing area that is prone to contraction. Which type of graft would be most appropriate to minimize the risk of contraction?

options.A: Thiersch graft, due to its minimal contraction
options.B: Wolfe graft, due to its full-thickness nature
options.C: Split-thickness graft, because it can cover larger areas
options.D: Composite graft, because it includes skin and underlying tissue

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Wolfe graft, due to its full-thickness nature Explanation: A Wolfe graft is a full-thickness skin graft that is less prone to contraction compared to split-thickness grafts like the Thiersch graft. This makes it more suitable for areas where minimizing contraction is important. Feature Thiersch Graft (Split-Thickness Skin Graft) Wolfe Graft (Full-Thickness Skin Graft) Type of Skin Grafting Split-thickness Full-thickness Composition Epidermis + part of dermis Epidermis + full thickness of dermis Graft Size Large grafts can be taken Only small grafts can be taken Graft Survival Easier More difficult Donor Site Healing Heals spontaneously, allowing repeated grafts Permanent defect develops, preventing repeated grafts Graft Contraction Significant contraction, leading to poor cosmetic appearance Lesser contraction, better cosmetic appearance Common Donor Sites Inner thigh, upper arm, flexor aspect of forearm, abdominal wall Upper eyelid, retro auricular skin, supraclavicular skin, antecubital skin, inframammary skin, inguinal skin, genital skin, gluteal skin Donor Site Exclusions None Axilla is not used as a donor site Advantages of Harvesting Allows calibration of thickness and large area coverage Calibration of thickness for small but thick grafts Thiersch Graft, a type of split-thickness skin graft (Option A and C): is more prone to contraction because it only includes part of the dermis. While they are useful for covering larger areas, they do not minimize contraction as effectively as full-thickness grafts. Composite grafts (Option D): include skin and underlying tissue (like cartilage or muscle). They are often used for complex reconstructive needs but are not specifically designed to minimize contraction compared to full-thickness skin grafts. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1917 Evolution of skin grafting for treatment of burns - ScienceDirect

questions.question: During a skin grafting procedure, the surgeon opts for a tool that can precisely control the thickness of the graft to ensure uniformity. Which of the following instruments is most appropriate for this task?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Electric dermatome Explanation: An electric dermatome allows for precise control over the thickness of the skin graft, producing a uniform graft that is ideal for transplantation. Humby's knife is another specialized surgical instrument designed for harvesting thin, uniform skin grafts with precision. Skin graft mesher is another instrument used in grafting. It helps to increase the surface area of smaller grafts. It is used for large wounds. Surgical scissors (Option A): Not suitable for harvesting grafts as they lack the precision and uniformity needed. Dermabrader (Option B): Used for removing superficial layers, not for harvesting grafts. Ferris-Smith forceps (Option C): These are used for tissue manipulation, not for graft harvesting.
